GWAS Pipeline ®

Scalable genomic data analysis platform to interrogate biobank-scale genomic datasets Technical pipeline for genome wide association studies (GWAS)

Genome wide association study (GWAS) is used to identify commonly occurring genetic variants that contribute to disease risk by searching the genome for small variations, called single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). On successful identification, SNPs can be used to develop effective prevention and treatment strategies for the disease. Researchers and scientists are faced with challenges such as:

  • Large amount of data hosted on several portals making it difficult to organize and accessible to all
  • Lack of UI tools to visualize custom data and make preliminary data analysis due to memory issues
  • Limited understanding and exposure to operate cloud computing infrastructure leading to cumbersome debugging routines
  • Lack of understanding of open-source tools for extracting sequenced reads to find overexpressed genes; difficulty in chaining inputs and outputs in a cohesive manner
  • Eliminating confounding variables for decreasing uncertainty

Our Solution

Aganitha acts as accelerators for bioinformaticians. We provide a robust, scalable domain specific language (DSL) for scientists to develop genomic pipelines without in-depth knowledge of underlying technology used. It is powered by:

  • Enhanced open source tools to provide outputs in a myriad of formats (HTML, jupyter, web viewers and more)
  • A high performance computing platform, open source tools such as Hail and Luigi to enable a distributed, scalable computing system
  • Integration with databases like VEP (variant effect predictor), gnomad
  • VCF files obtained as outputs make it easier for bioinformaticians to conduct preliminary analysis

Highlights

In built functions

Several cohort builder classes for filtering variants based on different parameters

Data manipulation

Filter, group, aggregate and visualize genomic data, control for confounding caused by population stratification using Hail

Unified genomic data representation

A single interface for working with all kinds of genomic data powered by Hail’s matrix table

Scalable

Easy to use with small and biobank-scale genomic data; scale from laptop to large compute cluster or cloud with the same code base

Integration

Contains python wrapper classes for defining concepts like cohorts, analysis results, variant effect predictor (VEP) and more

Benefits

  • Understand Mendelian violations in trios, prune variants in linkage disequilibrium, analyze genetic similarity between samples, and compute sample scores and variant loadings using PCA
  • Perform variant, gene-burden and eQTL association analyses using linear, logistic, and linear mixed regression, and estimate heritability
  • Reusability of tools saving time to rewrite from scratch and regeneratable results for future
  • Ability to use scalable cloud computing without learning about nitty gritty details
  • Caching of runs saving computational cost
